channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Coronavirus Live Updates: All 50 States Have Begun to Reopen
item.description: The C.D.C. quietly released more guidance for reopening. Trump threatened to withhold federal funds from Michigan for expanding mail-in voting. Hundreds of migrant children have been deported during the pandemic.
item.media:credit: Jessica Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: A customer ordering takeout on her phone in the outdoor dining area of a restaurant in West Hartford, Conn., on Wednesday.

item.title: 10 Years Old, Tearful and Confused After a Sudden Deportation
item.description: Since the coronavirus broke out, the Trump administration has deported hundreds of migrant children alone — in some cases, without notifying their families.
item.dc:creator: Caitlin Dickerson

item.title: Michigan Dams Breached, Forcing Evacuations in Midland: Live Updates
item.description: The National Weather Service issued a flash-flood warning for areas near the Tittabawassee River. The disaster was compounded by the effects of the coronavirus.

item.title: In a World ‘So Upside Down,’ the Virus Is Taking a Toll on Young People’s Mental Health
item.description: The shuttering of the American education system has cut off young people from school staff members who helped them navigate the pressures of adolescence and cope with trauma.
item.dc:creator: Dan Levin
item.media:description: Jael Hernandez, right, is a single mother of three children, including her eldest, Jizelle, left. The pressure of working two jobs remotely, on top of helping with her children’s online learning, has left Ms. Hernandez with little time to handle their emotional needs.

item.title: A New Entry in the Race for a Coronavirus Vaccine: Hope
item.description: Scientists are increasingly optimistic that a vaccine can be produced in record time. But getting it manufactured and distributed will pose huge challenges.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer, Knvul Sheikh and Noah Weiland
item.media:description: Vaccine vials in the Clinical Biomanufacturing Facility in Oxford, Britain.

item.title: Coronavirus Shut Down the ‘Experience Economy.’ Can It Come Back?
item.description: Large-scale gatherings are on hold for the foreseeable future. That is taking a toll on the live events industry and society at large.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.media:description: Live events like the Coachella festival in California had become increasingly important to the U.S. economy.

item.title: Dam Disaster Threatens Major Dow Chemical Complex and Superfund Project
item.description: Floodwaters surged toward Midland, Mich., and one of the nation’s most extensive toxic cleanup sites, raising concerns of a wider environmental fallout from the dam disaster.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:description: Water overrunning the Sanford Dam on Tuesday, one of two dams in central Michigan that failed because of heavy rains.

item.title: Pompeo Defends Firing of Inspector General, Denying It Was Retaliation
item.description: Congressional officials said the inspector general was examining several areas of policy and potential misuse of government resources that had raised concerns about Mr. Pompeo’s actions.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Edward Wong
item.media:description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo during a State Department briefing on Wednesday.

item.title: Prototype Vaccine Protects Monkeys From Coronavirus
item.description: A series of animal experiments may point the way to an effective human vaccine, scientists said.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:credit: Tony Luong for The New York Times
item.media:description: Katherine McMahan, a research assistant working on research related to a new coronavirus vaccine at the Center for Virology and Vaccine Research at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center in Boston.

item.title: Trump Makes False Claim About Michigan Secretary of State and Mail Voting
item.description: President Trump threatened to withhold federal funding for Michigan and Nevada if the states moved forward in expanding vote by mail.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein, Nick Corasaniti and Annie Karni
item.media:description: A voter dropped off a ballot that was mailed to her in Dayton, Ohio, last month.

item.title: On Politics: The Economy’s Biggest Threat Is …
item.description: Financial warnings and reopener’s remorse: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: A Struggling Stimulus Program
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: John Taggart for The New York Times

item.title: Hospitals Move Into Next Phase as New York Passes Viral Peak
item.description: A sharp drop in coronavirus patients was “like someone turned off the hose,” one doctor said. But the city’s health system faces challenges ahead.
item.dc:creator: Sheri Fink
item.category: New York City Health and Hospitals Corp
item.media:description: An empty bed at Elmhurst Hospital in Queens this month.

item.title: How the ‘Plandemic’ Movie and Its Falsehoods Spread Widely Online
item.description: Conspiracy theories about the pandemic have gained more traction than mainstream online events. Here’s how.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel, Ben Decker and Davey Alba

item.title: No More ‘Kneecap to Kneecap’ Talks: Coronavirus Hinders Military Recruiting
item.description: There is no substitute for face-to-face conversations when trying to get Americans to sign up to be service members. Boot camp outbreaks slow the pipeline, too.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Steinhauer
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Marine Corps Recruit Depot Parris Island (SC)
item.media:credit: Luke Sharrett for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Army recruiting station in Lexington, Ky., in 2018. The Army enlisted 5,500 fewer people in March than expected.

item.title: Salvage Firm Can Cut Into Titanic to Recover Telegraph, Judge Says
item.description: The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration opposes the operation to salvage the Marconi device and contends that the wreckage should not be disturbed.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor and Sandra E. Garcia
item.media:description: The Titanic leaving Southampton, England, in 1912.

item.title: Stock Markets: Live Updates
item.description: Live Stock Market News During the Coronavirus Pandemic
item.media:description: Fans at the Super Bowl in February. Last year, entertainment, food services, recreation, accommodations and art accounted for nearly $1.6 trillion in G.D.P.

item.title: Coronavirus World Updates: India cyclone, Brazil, China
item.description: The move by Brazil came amid debate over the drug’s efficacy and side effects. Around the globe, the hallmarks of an unsettling new normal emerged: flight attendants in hazmat suits, death sentences handed down on Zoom and fear that natural disasters could seed new outbreaks.
item.media:description: Coronavirus patients at the Gilberto Novaes municipal field hospital in Manaus, Brazil, on Monday.

item.title: 2 Dams Fail in Michigan, Forcing Thousands to Evacuate
item.description: The failure of the dams was expected to bring record-setting flooding, with the response complicated by the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor and Christine Hauser
item.media:credit: Kaytie Boomer/The Bay City Times, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A dam on Wixom Lake in Edenville, Mich., on Tuesday.

item.title: College in the Coronavirus Pandemic: No Fall Break and Home by Thanksgiving
item.description: As universities announce plans to bring back students, a pattern is emerging: shorter semesters to avoid late-fall infections.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler
item.media:credit: Elizabeth Conley/Houston Chronicle, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Rice University in Houston has extensive experience with crisis management because of a string of hurricanes hitting the city in recent years.

item.title: Abbas Declares Palestinians’ West Bank Security Commitments Null and Void
item.description: The Palestinian leader has made such assertions before, but this may not be a mere threat. The agreements have protected Israelis and preserved the Palestinian Authority’s political hold over the West Bank.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger and Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: Mahmoud Abbas, president of the Palestinian Authority, said Tuesday in Ramallah that the Palestinians were “absolved” of all commitments stemming from the Oslo peace accords.

item.title: New Conspiracy Theory, Familiar Path
item.description: President Trump’s baseless “Obamagate” charge illustrates how disinformation bubbles from the internet.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times

item.title: Roe v. Wade Plaintiff Was Paid to Switch Sides, Documentary Says
item.description: Before dying in 2017, Norma McCorvey said she had supported anti-abortion groups only for the money.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross and Aimee Ortiz
item.media:description: Norma McCorvey, right, the plaintiff in Roe v. Wade, and the lawyer Gloria Allred during an abortion rights rally in Burbank, Calif., in 1989.

item.title: Amid Hydroxychloroquine Uproar, Real Studies of Drug Are Suffering
item.description: The political fights around a malaria drug that President Trump says he takes daily have impeded studies into whether it works to prevent coronavirus infection or treat Covid-19 early.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.category: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases
item.media:description: Bottles of hydroxychloroquine. President Trump said this week that he had been taking the drug as a preventative measure against the coronavirus.

item.title: W.H.O. Members Reject Trump’s Demands but Agree to Study Its Virus Response
item.description: The outcome left the United States isolated as officials from China, Russia and the European Union chided Mr. Trump over his heated threats.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Andrew Jacobs
item.media:credit: Christopher Black/World Health Organization, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, the director general of the World Health Organization, has supported an examination of his organization’s response but reiterated the need for global cooperation.

item.title: Biden Calls Out ‘Anti-Semitism’ on the Left and Criticizes Israeli Policies
item.description: “Criticism of Israel’s policy is not anti-Semitism,” the former vice president told donors. “But too often that criticism from the left morphs into anti-Semitism.”
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher
item.media:description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. has been working to reach out to progressives, especially younger ones, many of whom have been critical of Israel’s treatment of Palestinians.

item.title: Pompeo Declined Interview Request From Inspector General About Saudi Arms Sales
item.description: The secretary of state instead offered written answers. He was aware of the inquiry and the specific lines of questioning about his decision to resume the sales.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and David E. Sanger
item.media:description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo recommended that President Trump fire the inspector general.

item.title: Susan Pompeo Draws Scrutiny in Inquiry Over Dry Cleaning and Dog Walking
item.description: The wife of Secretary of State Mike Pompeo is at the center of an investigation into whether a State Department employee was assigned to do household tasks.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:description: Susan Pompeo arriving in Addis Ababa, Ethopia, in February with her husband, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo.

item.title: Why Clean Shirts Become the Stuff of Dirty Laundry
item.description: Government watchdogs say skirting the rules against subordinates doing chores hints at a broader disregard for ethics restrictions.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.category: Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington
item.media:description: The ethics troubles that led in 2018 to the downfall of Scott Pruitt, the former administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, included claims of dry-cleaning runs by his security detail.

item.title: Election Watchdog, Dormant for Months, Can Finally Move Into Action
item.description: With the confirmation of James E. Trainor III, the Federal Election Commission can function again. But warring ideologies among its members raise questions about what it can accomplish.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca R. Ruiz
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Caroline Brehman, via Getty Images
item.media:description: James E. Trainor III testifying at his confirmation hearing before the Senate Rules and Administration Committee in March.

item.title: Emulating Democrats, G.O.P. Ties House Hopes to Diverse Recruits
item.description: “We need candidates other than boring old white people”: House Republicans are betting on a group of diverse candidates with compelling biographies to help them reclaim lost seats.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Mike Garcia, Republican of California, was sworn into Congress on Tuesday.

item.title: Authorities Seek Forfeiture of Ancient Gilgamesh Tablet From Hobby Lobby
item.description: The “Gilgamesh Dream Tablet” was displayed at the Museum of the Bible in Washington until the authorities seized it in 2019.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:credit: U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York
item.media:description: A cuneiform tablet bearing part of the Epic of Gilgamesh.

item.title: California Reopening: What Are the Phases?
item.description: Here’s what you need to know about the state’s plan to reopen for business during the coronavirus pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Sona Patel
item.media:credit: Ryan Young for The New York Times
item.media:description: Venice Beach on May 17.

item.title: Johnson & Johnson to End Talc-Based Baby Powder Sales in North America
item.description: The company has faced thousands of lawsuits from cancer patients who claim that its talc was contaminated with asbestos, a known carcinogen, and that the company knew of the risks.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany Hsu and Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:credit: Jens Mortensen for The New York Times
item.media:description: A jury in California ordered Johnson & Johnson to pay more than $29 million to a woman who alleged that asbestos in its talc-based powder products had caused her cancer.

item.title: Mnuchin and Powell Warn of Economic Scarring, and Offer Divergent Solutions
item.description: The Treasury secretary and Fed chair said economic damage could last. One prescribed rapid reopening, the other robust policy action.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and Jeanna Smialek
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: Steven Mnuchin, the Treasury secretary, in March on Capitol Hill.
